span.text: The thousand arms of the forest were grey, and its million fingers silver. In a sky of dark green-blue-like slate the stars were bleak and brilliant like splintered ice.

span.text: All that thickly wooded and sparsely tenanted countryside was stiff with a bitter and brittle frost. The black hollows between the trunks of the trees looked like bottomless, black caverns of that Scandinavian hell, a hell of incalculable cold.

span.text: Even the square stone tower of the church looked northern to the point of heathenry, as if it were some barbaric tower among the sea rocks of Iceland. It was a queer night for anyone to explore a churchyard. But, on the other hand, perhaps it was worth exploring.

span.text: It rose abruptly out of the ashen wastes of forest in a sort of hump or shoulder of green turf that looked grey in the starlight. Most of the graves were on a slant, and the path leading up to the church was as steep as a staircase.

span.text: On the top of the hill, in the one flat and prominent place, was the monument for which the place was famous.

span.text: It contrasted strangely with the featureless graves all round, for it was the work of one of the greatest sculptors of modern Europe; and yet his fame was at once forgotten in the fame of the man whose image he had made.

span.text: It showed, by touches of the small silver pencil of starlight, the massive metal figure of a soldier recumbent, the strong hands sealed in an everlasting worship, the great head pillowed upon a gun.

span.text: The venerable face was bearded, or rather whiskered, in the old, heavy Colonel Newcome fashion. The uniform, though suggested with the few strokes of simplicity, was that of modern war. By his right side lay a sword, of which the tip was broken off; on the left side lay a Bible.

span.text: On glowing summer afternoons wagonettes came full of Americans and cultured suburbans to see the sepulchre; but even then they felt the vast forest land with its one dumpy dome of churchyard and church as a place oddly dumb and neglected.

span.text: In this freezing darkness of mid-winter one would think he might be left alone with the stars. Nevertheless, in the stillness of those stiff woods a wooden gate creaked, and two dim figures dressed in black climbed up the little path to the tomb.

span.text: So faint was that frigid starlight that nothing could have been traced about them except that while they both wore black, one man was enormously big, and the other (perhaps by contrast) almost startlingly small.

span.text: They went up to the great graven tomb of the historic warrior, and stood for a few minutes staring at it. There was no human, perhaps no living, thing for a wide circle; and a morbid fancy might well have wondered if they were human themselves.

span.text: “Where does a wise man hide a pebble?”

span.text: And the tall man answered in a low voice: “On the beach.”

span.text: The small man nodded, and after a short silence said: “Where does a wise man hide a leaf?”

span.text: There was another stillness, and then the tall man resumed: “Do you mean that when a wise man has to hide a real diamond he has been known to hide it among sham ones?”

span.text: “No, no,” said the little man with a laugh, “we will let bygones be bygones.”

span.text: He stamped his cold feet for a second or two, and then said: “I’m not thinking of that at all, but of something else; something rather peculiar. Just strike a match, will you?”

span.text: The big man fumbled in his pocket, and soon a scratch and a flare painted gold the whole flat side of the monument.

span.text: On it was cut in black letters the well-known words which so many Americans had reverently read: “Sacred to the Memory of General Sir Arthur St. Clare, Hero and Martyr, who Always Vanquished his Enemies and Always Spared Them, and Was Treacherously Slain by Them At Last.

span.text: The match burnt the big man’s fingers, blackened, and dropped. He was about to strike another, but his small companion stopped him. “That’s all right, Flambeau, old man; I saw what I wanted. Or, rather, I didn’t see what I didn’t want.

span.text: And now we must walk a mile and a half along the road to the next inn, and I will try to tell you all about it. For Heaven knows a man should have a fire and ale when he dares tell such a story.”

span.text: They descended the precipitous path, they relatched the rusty gate, and set off at a stamping, ringing walk down the frozen forest road.

span.text: They had gone a full quarter of a mile before the smaller man spoke again. He said: “Yes; the wise man hides a pebble on the beach. But what does he do if there is no beach? Do you know anything of that great St. Clare trouble?”

span.text: “I know nothing about English generals, Father Brown,” answered the large man, laughing, “though a little about English policemen. I only know that you have dragged me a precious long dance to all the shrines of this fellow, whoever he is.

span.text: I am beginning to be a bit tired of his magnificent personality, especially as I don’t in the least know who he was. What are you hunting for in all these crypts and effigies?”

span.text: “I must divide it into two parts,” remarked the priest. “First there is what everybody knows; and then there is what I know. Now, what everybody knows is short and plain enough. It is also entirely wrong.”

span.text: “Right you are,” said the big man called Flambeau cheerfully. “Let’s begin at the wrong end. Let’s begin with what everybody knows, which isn’t true.”

span.text: The public knows that Arthur St. Clare was a great and successful English general. It knows that after splendid yet careful campaigns both in India and Africa he was in command against Brazil when the great Brazilian patriot Olivier issued his ultimatum.

span.text: And it knows that after his capture, and to the abhorrence of the civilised world, St. Clare was hanged on the nearest tree. He was found swinging there after the Brazilians had retired, with his broken sword hung round his neck.”

span.text: “And that popular story is untrue?” suggested Flambeau.

span.text: “No,” said his friend quietly, “that story is quite true, so far as it goes.”

span.text: “Well, I think it goes far enough!” said Flambeau; “but if the popular story is true, what is the mystery?”

span.text: “General Sir Arthur St. Clare,” he said, “came of a family in which madness was hereditary; and his whole aim was to keep this from his daughter, and even, if possible, from his future son-in-law. Rightly or wrongly, he thought the final collapse was close, and resolved on suicide.

span.text: Yet ordinary suicide would blazon the very idea he dreaded. As the campaign approached the clouds came thicker on his brain; and at last in a mad moment he sacrificed his public duty to his private. He rushed rashly into battle, hoping to fall by the first shot.

span.text: “Yours is a clean story,” cried Father Brown, deeply moved. “A sweet, pure, honest story, as open and white as that moon. Madness and despair are innocent enough. There are worse things, Flambeau.”

span.speech: “Father—father,” cried Flambeau with the French gesture and stepping yet more rapidly forward, “do you mean it was worse than that?”

span.text: “Worse than that,” said Paul like a grave echo. And they plunged into the black cloister of the woodland, which ran by them in a dim tapestry of trunks, like one of the dark corridors in a dream.
span.speech: “Worse than that,” said Paul like a grave echo. And they plunged into the black cloister of the woodland, which ran by them in a dim tapestry of trunks, like one of the dark corridors in a dream.

span.text: They were soon in the most secret entrails of the wood, and felt close about them foliage that they could not see, when the priest said again:

span.text: They were soon in the most secret entrails of the wood, and felt close about them foliage that they could not see, when the priest said again:

span.text: “Where does a wise man hide a leaf? In the forest. But what does he do if there is no forest?”
span.speech: “Where does a wise man hide a leaf? In the forest. But what does he do if there is no forest?”

span.text: “Where does a wise man hide a leaf?

span.text: But what does he do if there is no forest?”
span.speech: But what does he do if there is no forest?”

span.text: “Well, well,” cried Flambeau irritably, “what does he do?”
span.speech: “Well, well,” cried Flambeau irritably, “what does he do?”

span.text: “Well, well,” cried Flambeau irritably, “what does he do?”
span.speech: “Well, well,” cried Flambeau irritably, “what does he do?”

span.text: “He grows a forest to hide it in,” said the priest in an obscure voice. “A fearful sin.”
span.speech: “He grows a forest to hide it in,” said the priest in an obscure voice. “A fearful sin.”

span.text: “Look here,” cried his friend impatiently, for the dark wood and the dark saying got a little on his nerves; “will you tell me this story or not? What other evidence is there to go on?”

span.text: What other evidence is there to go on?”
span.speech: What other evidence is there to go on?”

span.text: “There are three more bits of evidence,” said the other, “that I have dug up in holes and corners; and I will give them in logical rather than chronological order.
span.speech: “There are three more bits of evidence,” said the other, “that I have dug up in holes and corners; and I will give them in logical rather than chronological order.

span.text: First of all, of course, our authority for the issue and event of the battle is in Olivier’s own dispatches, which are lucid enough.
span.speech: First of all, of course, our authority for the issue and event of the battle is in Olivier’s own dispatches, which are lucid enough.

span.text: He was entrenched with two or three regiments on the heights that swept down to the Black River, on the other side of which was lower and more marshy ground.

span.text: He was entrenched with two or three regiments on the heights that swept down to the Black River, on the other side of which was lower and more marshy ground.

span.text: Beyond this again was gently rising country, on which was the first English outpost, supported by others which lay, however, considerably in its rear.
span.speech: Beyond this again was gently rising country, on which was the first English outpost, supported by others which lay, however, considerably in its rear.

span.text: The British forces as a whole were greatly superior in numbers; but this particular regiment was just far enough from its base to make Olivier consider the project of crossing the river to cut it off.

span.text: By sunset, however, he had decided to retain his own position, which was a specially strong one.
span.speech: By sunset, however, he had decided to retain his own position, which was a specially strong one.

span.text: By sunset, however, he had decided to retain his own position, which was a specially strong one.
span.speech: By sunset, however, he had decided to retain his own position, which was a specially strong one.

span.text: At daybreak next morning he was thunderstruck to see that this stray handful of English, entirely unsupported from their rear, had flung themselves across the river, half by a bridge to the right, and the other half by a ford higher up,

span.text: and were massed upon the marshy bank below him.

span.text: “That they should attempt an attack with such numbers against such a position was incredible enough; but Olivier noticed something yet more extraordinary.
span.speech: “That they should attempt an attack with such numbers against such a position was incredible enough; but Olivier noticed something yet more extraordinary.

span.text: “That they should attempt an attack with such numbers against such a position was incredible enough; but Olivier noticed something yet more extraordinary.
span.speech: “That they should attempt an attack with such numbers against such a position was incredible enough; but Olivier noticed something yet more extraordinary.

span.text: For instead of attempting to seize more solid ground, this mad regiment, having put the river in its rear by one wild charge, did nothing more, but stuck there in the mire like flies in treacle.
span.speech: For instead of attempting to seize more solid ground, this mad regiment, having put the river in its rear by one wild charge, did nothing more, but stuck there in the mire like flies in treacle.

span.text: Needless to say, the Brazilians blew great gaps in them with artillery, which they could only return with spirited but lessening rifle fire. Yet they never broke; and Olivier’s curt account ends with a strong tribute of admiration for the mystic valour of these imbeciles.

span.text: ‘Our line then advanced finally,’ writes Olivier, ‘and drove them into the river; we captured General St. Clare himself and several other officers. The colonel and the major had both fallen in the battle.

span.text: I cannot resist saying that few finer sights can have been seen in history than the last stand of this extraordinary regiment; wounded officers picking up the rifles of dead soldiers, and the general himself facing us on horseback bareheaded and with a broken sword.’

span.text: On what happened to the general afterwards Olivier is as silent as Captain Keith.”

span.text: “Well,” grunted Flambeau, “get on to the next bit of evidence.”
